title: Woman's life-changing gesture for girls forced to sleep in sheds during their period
text:

Primary school teacher Ann Marcer, 67, had worked in education for almost 40 years, so as retirement approached, she and her husband planned a trip of a lifetime, driving their camper van around Europe and hiking where they could.

But just two months before they were due to hit the road, her husband died suddenly.

In the midst of grief and with retirement looming, Ann didn’t feel confident enough to go travelling on her own, but still felt like she wanted to see more of the world.

‘A friend had volunteered with an organisation called Voluntary Services Overseas (VSO), a not-for-profit organisation that sends teachers, medics and aid workers to some of the poorest countries,’ says Ann.

‘It seemed like a good way to see the world, while also doing a bit of good.’

Tentatively, Ann signed up, and at first she had no idea where she would be stationed.

She packed up the house she had shared with her husband for many years, putting everything into storage so she could rent it out for two years.

She would be leaving behind her two grown-up children and two grandchildren, but the family was fully supportive.

Just a few months before Ann was due to begin with VSO, she found out she would be going to Nepal in South Asia.

‘I was very excited at the prospect,’ she says.

‘It’s somewhere my husband and I had always planned to go, because we both loved hiking and the mountains.’

Because Ann had spent 15 years as a head teacher of a primary school, she was asked to take part in a programme that trained local Nepalese teachers, funded by UK Aid.

‘I packed up my entire life into a backpack and small suitcase that weighed just 30kg, and flew to Kathmandhu,’ she says.

‘It just goes to show how little of what we own we actually need.’

Ann was stationed in a town not far from the Annapurna mountains.

Her role would cover 12 rural schools, the closest of which was an hour’s walk away, while the longest would take five hours on a bus with a three hour hike on the other side.

Changing lives

‘I’d had six weeks of Nepali lessons, so I understood a little bit of the language,’ she says.

‘On my first day I was introduced to some of the local VSO staff, and one young woman asked, with genuine concern, “You’re very old, are you sure you can do this job?”

'Her own mother was my age and had had such a hard life that she couldn’t imagine her doing it.’

But, in fact, Ann relished the challenge.

Walking for so many miles each day meant her fitness levels rocketed and she dropped from a size 14 to a size 10.

One of Ann’s most important tasks was improving conditions for girls at school.

‘It was wonderful when I met the girls for the first time,’ she remembers.

(Image: Rowan Griffiths/Daily Mirror)

‘They were very interested that I’d had a career – many of them don’t make it all the way through school, because of pressures to work in the fields to feed their family, or to stay at home and care for relatives.’

One of the issues that Ann noticed right away was shame among girls about having their periods.

In some parts of Nepal, a practice called chhaupadi – in which menstruating women are banned from the home and made to sleep in cattle sheds or ‘exile huts’– is still followed, despite having been made illegal in 2017.

Many women and children have died of smoke inhalation, fire or snake bites in these makeshift huts.

Although she didn’t see the practice first hand, Ann soon became aware that when girls were on their period, they often stopped coming to school altogether.

‘I noticed how bad the girls’ toilets were in many of my schools,’ says Ann.

‘Lots of them didn’t have any running water, so if the girls came on their period early they wouldn’t even be able to have a wash.

'Some of them had no toilet doors, so there was no privacy.

'We set about making these better, and we also started a programme teaching girls to make their own washable sanitary pads to use instead of rags.

'Soon, they were showing the younger girls how to make them too.’

Total devastation

Eighteen months into her time in Nepal, the country was rocked by an enormous earthquake, measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale.

‘It was the most frightening few minutes of my life,’ remembers Ann.

‘The noise was terrific: things were falling off shelves in my flat and I could see metal frames buckling and windows popping out.

'You’re supposed to stay in the building and go to the corner where the walls are strongest, but panic took over.

'I was just terrified that something was going to fall on me, so I ran until I reached the rice terraces behind my building.’

The rice fields were filled with people desperate to escape the tall buildings.

Despite everyone having been through the same ordeal, Ann was struck with just how many locals came to see if she was OK.

‘They were terrified too, but that’s Nepali people for you – always looking out for others,’ she says.

Ann managed to text her daughter a brief message before the network cut out: ‘Earthquake, I am OK.’

In total, 9,000 people were killed and hundreds of thousands were made homeless.

Despite being just 25 miles from the epicentre, the damage to the town was only moderate, but the impact on the mountain schools and villages was devastating.

‘One of my students was killed and many, many saw their homes destroyed,’ she says.

‘Because it is difficult and expensive to get concrete to the remote villages, most buildings are held together by mud and wood, which just didn’t hold out.

'VSO offered to repatriate me immediately, but all I could think of was my girls.

'I had survived the earthquake, I could survive the aftermath.

(Image: News Agency/REX Shutterstock)

'I thought, “There’s lots to do here – let’s get on with it.”’

UNICEF launched a project to repair and rebuild the schools as quickly as possible, so that the children’s education wouldn’t be irrevocably interrupted.

Right away, Ann began to help organise supplies.

‘We reached remote schools where teachers were still trying to teach kids beneath the trees,’ she says.

‘I remember one school where the classrooms had been completely destroyed, and the head teacher just sobbing, saying, “How can we help the children now?”

'But we organised tractors full of supplies to be taken up the mountains, and within weeks we were able to get things up and running.’

Ann worked every single day for six weeks.

‘I should have been exhausted, but because I had a purpose I powered on,’ she says. ‘It felt good to see the impact our work was having.’

Ann also helped arrange a programme to help the girls overcome the trauma of experiencing an earthquake, working through their fears with art and music.

‘Many of the girls had seen their homes and villages destroyed, and it is a lot to cope with,’ she says.

‘I was very blasé about the impact it had on me, until much later when I got home and was standing in my daughter’s kitchen.

When the washing machine went onto spin mode, I was out of the door in a second.

'I didn’t realise I’d been affected in that way.’

After two years in Nepal, Ann returned home and did so knowing the project had been a huge success.

She is still in touch with many of the local VSO workers, many of whom call her their ‘biddeshi mum’, which translates as foreigner mum.

On Mother’s Day, she receives cards from them.

Ann has been back to Nepal for two shorter projects and now gives talks about the power of volunteering in retirement.

She even spoke at the Tory Party Conference about the positive impact that UK Aid can have, and has been awarded an OBE for services to charity.

There’s one small problem, though… ‘I’m supposed to be collecting my OBE in November, but I’ll be in Nepal then,’ she says with a laugh.

‘So I’ve had to postpone it.’

There aren’t many people who would put off meeting the Queen because they are busy volunteering, but then Ann isn’t an ordinary woman.

‘This whole experience has given me a completely different dimension to my retirement – it’s given me a different purpose and a different way of looking at things,’ she says.

‘I gained as much from the volunteering role as the people I was working with, and I wouldn’t change it for the world.’

For more information on VSO or to donate, go to CLICK HERE. The project Ann was working on was funded by UK Aid, a government-funded project currently changing the lives of 3 million of the world’s poorest people.
description: After decades teaching at a school in Devon, Ann Marcer, 67, decided to spend her golden years doing something unusual…
